div.l: ¶ Now certes qduod this Oswolde the reue
I pray you alle that ye nought you greue
If I onswere somdell ⁊and sette his hof
For leful is to force wᵗith force of the swof
This dronken myller hath told vs here
How bi gyled was this carpyntere
Perauenutre in skorne for I am on
And bi youre leue I shal quyte him anon
Right in churles termes I shal speke
I prey to god his necke mot to breke
He can wel fynden in myn eye a stalke
But in his owne he connot fynde a balke
Here endeth the ꝓprolog
Here bygynneth the Reues tale
AT trompyngton not fer fro Cam—briggeCau briggeCambrigge
Ther goth a broke ⁊and ouer that a brigge
Vpon the whiche ther stondeth a mulle
And this is verrey soth that I you telle
A myller was ther dwellyng mony a day
As eny pocok he was stoute ⁊and gay
Pypen he couthe ⁊and fysshen ⁊and nettes bete
And turne cuppes ⁊and wel wrastell ⁊and shete
And bi his belt he bar a long panade
And swerd ful trenchant is the blade
A Ioly poppar͗e he bar bi his pouche
Ther was no man for perell durst him touche
A sheffeld whitell he bar in his hose
Round was his face ⁊and camoys was his nose
As pylled as a nape was his skolle
He was a market beter at the folle
He durst not wᵗith hond vpon hym ley
That he ne swere a non he shulde a by add characte
